awd_titl_txt: ABI Development:  Computational infrastructure for phylogenetic analysis in the R environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past several decades, phylogenetic trees, the graphs that are used to represent the ancestor-descendant relationships between gene sequences, populations, or species, have become integral in scientific research across an increasingly widening range of biological disciplines such as ecology, evolutionary biology, molecular biology, comparative genomics, and development. Phylogenies too have begun to see application outside of biology in such diverse fields of study as comparative linguistics, anthropology, and forensic science. Meanwhile, the computational environment known as 'R' has developed into one of the leading platforms for scientific computing. The strength of R comes from the literally thousands of contributed function libraries (called "packages") developed and distributed for free by computational scientists and developers that are not members of the R core development team. Because of these contributions, R has grown into the preeminent software platform for manipulating, visualizing, and analyzing phylogenetic trees. That said, the capability to actually estimate phylogenetic trees from data in R remains relatively limited. The major objective of this award is to substantially extend the toolkit that is available to undertake phylogeny estimation in the R scientific computing environment. This toolkit will be built using an open development model and will be distributed as a free and open-source resource to the national and international scientific communities. Among the major advantages of developing software for scientific computing in R is that so doing dramatically facilitates scientific reproducibility by allowing all stages of the data analysis pipeline to be built into a single, fully reproducible workflow from open source components.

This research will create new, open-source, and freely distributed software tools that will be of broad utility throughout the phylogenetic scientific community and beyond. The general goal is computational infrastructure development for phylogenetics in R. These investigators will focus on four specific objectives in particular: (1) the development and application of methods to compute distances between trees; (2) the development of new consensus and average tree methods; (3) the development of joint species-tree estimation methods based on likelihood; and, finally, (4) the application of visualization tools for sets of trees and phylogenetic networks. They focus specifically on these research objectives because they interact in particularly interesting ways and because they reflect areas in which substantial research is needed; however, research on these topics will likely result in unanticipated discoveries in fundamentally new areas. The award will also support postdoctoral and graduate training, the latter via an intensive, phylogeny methods boot camp for young developers. This training objective will be undertaken with the aim of helping to form the next generation of computational phylogenetic biologists and will target for participation graduate students from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. Phylogenetic tools from this project will be hosted on the CRAN at https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/phytools/index.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A phylogeny is a graph used to represent the relationship of entities associated via common descent, such as biological species or viruses in a disease outbreak. Methods for phylogenetic research fall into two broad categories. The first involves the estimation of phylogenies from data. As students, our initial exposure to a phylogenetic tree comes when one is used to illustrate the relationships of well-known groups, such as the major lineages of vertebrates. What this picture obscures is the fact that real phylogenies must be estimated using data obtained from the entities in our analysis, such as their gene or genome sequences. The methodologies underlying phylogenetic tree estimation, often called 'phylogeny inference,' have progressed substantially and continue to evolve in response to changes in the type and scale of data, and to technological advances in computation. The second major research area in phylogenetics is what is known as phylogenetic comparative analysis. This involves using phylogenies to make inferences about the evolutionary process itself, often with the help of other characteristics of the biological entities of our tree. For instance, if we were curious about the role of ecological opportunity in lizard diversification, we might use a phylogeny to model the evolution of ecological traits as a function of competitor richness. Likewise, if we were interested in the impact of host species on the geographic spread of a host-switching virus, we might use a viral phylogeny to model rate variation in spatial dispersion among hosts.

Both tree estimation and comparative methods are computer-intensive. In recent years, the computing environment R has become widely-adopted across numerous scientific research areas. R is at once a software, a computing environment, and a programming language. Although 'base R' (R's core operating system) provides a diverse toolkit for modeling and statistical analysis, the capabilities of R in specialized disciplines, such as phylogenetics, derive entirely from what are called contributed packages: libraries of R functions whose development is normally led by computational scientists, programmers, and researchers not part of the core R development team. In phylogenetics, a diverse ecosystem of R packages has arisen in recent years, and the two main packages of this award (phangorn and phytools) are close to the center of this ecosystem. The major goals of this project were as follows: (1) to extend the infrastructure for phylogenetic analysis in R; (2) to undertake research on a set of specific areas of phylogenetic methodology; (3) to create and disseminate open source computing infrastructure for phylogenetic and other biological analyses; and, finally, (4) to develop and implement new training workshops.

This award permitted phangorn and phytools to be built into two of the most important core R packages for phylogenetic research. At time of writing, phangorn, which is specialized in tree estimation and was significantly developed with the support of this award, had been cited over 3,400 times. phangorn counts as a 'core' R package of the phylogenetics ecosystem because over 40 other packages 'depend' on phangorn to run (meaning that they use phangorn internally).  phytools, a package focused on phylogenetic comparative analysis, had been cited over 9,100 times and is also a core R phylogenetics package, with nearly 50 other R packages depending on it. Both phangorn and phytools now consist of many thousands of lines of code, as well as user documentation collectively measuring over 350 pages in length. With the support of this award, phangorn offers a diverse range of methods for statistical phylogenetic tree inference, measuring distances between trees, computing consensus trees and networks, and a range of other purposes in phylogenetic biology. phytools supports a wide array of methods in phylogenetic comparative analysis, including discrete and continuous character models, ancestral state estimation, phylogenetic signal, and tree visualization, among many others. Apart from phangorn and phytools, this award also supported more limited work on the core phylogenetics packages ape and geiger, and the development of a web-based phylogenetic interface called Guane.

In addition to these scientific accomplishments, this award resulted in a variety of broader impacts relevant to science and society at large. The award supported the development, extension, and maintenance of critical scientific software that is distributed open source and totally free of charge, and is used by scientists globally. The PI of this award dedicated many hours per week responding to user inquiries about phylogenetic computing in R, and maintains a popular R phylogenetics development blog which receives thousands of page views per month. The award resulted in the training of three different postdocs. Finally, the award supported the development and implementation of an immersive R software development bootcamp and multiple R phylogenetic user workshops. These workshops have helped train both the next generation of phylogeny method users and software developers.
